messages.text: why do we use a fork of libuv instead of upstream?

elements.text: why do we use a fork of libuv instead of upstream?

messages.text: my understanding is that it’s mainly because upstream libuv doesn’t support the way we need to call the event loop because of our task system and upstream was uninterested in accepting the changes we made to support it even though it’s strictly more flexible

messages.text:
I ran into this issue as well (`"Package CompilerSupportLibraries_jll does not have JLLWrappers in its dependencies"`.

I’m finding that once the bad version of the package is in the 1.6 cache, it keeps on being reused, even in other projects.  Using `resolve` or `update` as <@U66GD0880> suggested doesn’t help.

Is there a good way to clean out the cache and/or otherwise clean this up after the fact?

messages.text: So there's a small issue with the SuiteSparse GraphBLAS binary builder on Yggdrasil. SuiteSparse GraphBLAS is now a somewhat separate library, with its own GitHub repo that is simply bundled with the larger SuiteSparse library. The issue is that SuiteSparse isn't updated as often as the GraphBLAS repo is. Ordinarily I would just point the script to the new repo, but the version number would then be behind, since GraphBLAS is younger. What should be done in this situation. Obviously waiting for the maintainer to update SuiteSparse is a possibility, it's done fairly regularly. But that leaves the jll noticeably behind quite often.

elements.text: So there's a small issue with the SuiteSparse GraphBLAS binary builder on Yggdrasil. Ordinarily I would just point the script to the new repo, but the version number would then be behind, since GraphBLAS is younger. What should be done in this situation. Obviously waiting for the maintainer to update SuiteSparse is a possibility, it's done fairly regularly. But that leaves the jll noticeably behind quite often.

messages.text: Are there any good reason to binary builder something when the package i want to wrap has releases on GitHub like this: <https://github.com/raysan5/raylib/releases/tag/3.5.0> ?
the main added value is that you can build for all platforms supported by Julia which are missing there (e.g., FreeBSD, all arm architectures, all musl-based platforms)

elements.text: the main added value is that you can build for all platforms supported by Julia which are missing there (e.g., FreeBSD, all arm architectures, all musl-based platforms)

messages.text: The other advantage is that if the library has dependencies, it's much easier to ensure that the correct julia-installed deps are picked up.

elements.text: The other advantage is that if the library has dependencies, it's much easier to ensure that the correct julia-installed deps are picked up.

messages.text: But there are quite a few instances where we do pick up vendor provided binaries. So it really depends on how hard it is to build.

elements.text: But there are quite a few instances where we do pick up vendor provided binaries. So it really depends on how hard it is to build.

elements.text: Julia (through pycall) and python's numba have a inter-operability problem due to llvm version. Could building numba in binarybuilder and distributing it as a JLL (i'm not sure how environment resolution would work on python...) be a step towards solving this problem?

messages.text: so, besides the broken macOS shards, the main problem I'm having for `HostBuildDependency` is this: <https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/BinaryBuilderBase.jl/pull/43/files#diff-48f90c9f7d86cf3e80c85fa66b31702f51d91cb8f6ce531575d7cc1f85f200f9R518> now we have platform-specific prefixes, and I've added a `platform` argument to `cleanup_dependencies` so the it cleans up only the dependencies for the given platform, but when the wizard needs to cleanup doesn't always know the platforms.  passing the platforms around would be quite a bit work.  is there any problem if we just cleanup everything in `prefix`, instead of `prefix/triplet/destdir`?

messages.text: so I was looking at <https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/BinaryBuilder.jl/issues/687> again, specifically the bit about `ncurses_jll` where one needs to set `TERMINFO` or `TERMINFINO_DIRS` suitably to make sure initializing it works. Back then the idea was that we adjust the `__init__` of the JLL to set them -- which we could now do. This would solve some issues for me, so I'd be willing to implement it (it's easy enough to do). BUT I am (still) worried whether this might not cause further issues down the road; specifically: this would mean that loading `ncurses_jll` (even indirectly) would modify the env vars of the Julia process, globally. While I am sure this would be fine for 99.9% cases, I wonder whether there are situations where it is not? Say, some user for some reason must set a custom TERMINO/TERMINFO_DIRS setting for their terminal; would we want to override that? Or perhaps only set those vars *if they are not already set*? But of course that, too, could cause issues (in cases where a user set them but not deliberately). Alas, the latter case is easy for a user to workaround (just unset those vars before loading Julia).... Am I worrying too much? Well, depends on who has to handle the bug reports, should they come in... :wink:

elements.text: suitably to make sure initializing it works. Back then the idea was that we adjust the

OS: Linux, Julia v"1.3.0"

I'm trying to build binary of a Foo C/C++ package using `run_wizard()` And when I run
```autoreconf -fiv
./configure --prefix=${prefix} --build=${MACHTYPE} --host=${target}```
I got this error `Configure has not found BLAS libraries for your system.  Please install BLAS or provide appropriate -l and -L flags to LIBS and LDFLAGS to allow configure to locate the dcopy function.`
from BB troubleshooting (<https://docs.binarybuilder.org/dev/troubleshooting/#Libraries-of-the-dependencies-can't-be-found>)
I added
```export LDFLAGS="-L${libdir}"
export LIBS="-l${libdir}"```
and ran `./configure...`
again. Now I am running into `C++ compiler cannot create executables` error.
The config.log has the following (looks like -V and -qversion are wrong flags
```configure:4950: $? = 0
configure:4939: c++ -v >&5
Using built-in specs.
COLLECT_GCC=/opt/x86_64-linux-gnu/bin/x86_64-linux-gnu-g++
COLLECT_LTO_WRAPPER=/opt/x86_64-linux-gnu/bin/../libexec/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/9.1.0/lto-wrapper
Target: x86_64-linux-gnu
Configured with: /workspace/srcdir/gcc-9.1.0/configure --prefix=/workspace/destdir --target=x86_64-linux-gnu --host=x86_64-linux-musl --build=x86_64-linux-musl --disable-multilib --disable-werror --enable-shared --enable-host-shared --enable-threads=posix --with-sysroot=/workspace/destdir/x86_64-linux-gnu/sys-root --program-prefix=x86_64-linux-gnu- --disable-bootstrap --with-arch=core2 --enable-languages=c,c++,fortran,objc,obj-c++
Thread model: posix
gcc version 9.1.0 (GCC)
configure:4950: $? = 0
configure:4939: c++ -V >&5
x86_64-linux-gnu-g++: error: unrecognized command line option '-V'
x86_64-linux-gnu-g++: fatal error: no input files
compilation terminated.
configure:4950: $? = 1
configure:4939: c++ -qversion >&5
x86_64-linux-gnu-g++: error: unrecognized command line option '-qversion'; did you mean '--version'?
x86_64-linux-gnu-g++: fatal error: no input files
compilation terminated.
configure:4950: $? = 1
configure:4970: checking whether the C++ compiler works
configure:4992: c++   -l/workspace/destdir/lib conftest.cpp -L/workspace/destdir/lib >&5
/opt/x86_64-linux-gnu/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/9.1.0/../../../../x86_64-linux-gnu/bin/ld: cannot find -l/workspace/destdir/lib
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
configure:4996: $? = 1
configure:5034: result: no```
From arch wiki <https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?id=163913> I see that this error is due to setting wrong ldflags.

What can I do to resolve this error? Am I missing something?

_dl_catch_exception at /usr/lib/libc.so.6 (unknown line)
_dl_open at /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (unknown line)```
